title-group.article-title: ‘It makes me feel that I’m still relevant’: A qualitative study of the views of nursing home residents on dignity therapy and taking part in a phase II randomised controlled trial of a palliative care psychotherapy

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Trials of dignity therapy (a palliative care psychotherapy) have shown self-reported benefits for participants from taking part, although more so in intervention than control groups. However, the sources of these benefits are unknown.

sec.title: Aim:
sec.p: The aim of this study was to explore and compare participants’ views on taking part in a mixed methods phase II randomised controlled trial of dignity therapy.

sec.title: Design:
sec.p: This was a qualitative study, using the framework approach to the analysis.

sec.title: Setting/participants:
sec.p: It involved residents, aged 65+, with no major cognitive impairment, living in one of 15 nursing/care homes in London, UK (49 residents at 1-week follow-up, 36 residents at 8-week follow-up).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Residents’ views were represented in nine themes, and three of these themes were evident only in the intervention group: views on the generativity document; generativity; and reminiscence. Six themes were evident in both groups: refocusing; making a contribution; interaction with the researcher or therapist; diversion; not helping with their problems; and cognitive impairment. Our findings support some of the proposed mechanisms of action for this palliative care intervention (pride, hopefulness, care tenor) but also draw attention to some of the potential problems of delivering the intervention. We show how residents could benefit from taking part in research, regardless of whether or not they receive the intended intervention.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Dignity therapy is likely to be beneficial to some care home residents, albeit the small minority who have the desire and the capacity to engage in such an intervention. Whether or not dignity therapy helps distressed residents, and the most effective way of screening for those who might benefit from it, need to be determined.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In many countries, as a result of an ageing population, increasing numbers of people will die in long-term care facilities such as nursing or care homes. Although many residents do not have a recognisable terminal illness, psychological and spiritual distress can result from multiple health problems, loss of function and awareness that they are likely to die in the home: consequently, there has been an increased focus on providing palliative care in these settings. Dignity therapy, an empirically-based brief life review style psychotherapy, has been developed specifically to address psychosocial and existential distress, enhance quality of life and bolster a sense of meaning, purpose and dignity among terminally ill people.1 The theoretical framework from which the therapy has been developed is a model of dignity developed from interviews with Canadian hospice patients.2 Seven themes from the model inform the structure, content and therapeutic tone of dignity therapy: generativity; continuity of self; role preservation; maintenance of pride; hopefulness; aftermath concerns; and care tenor (See Supplementary Data).1 The therapy involves an interview with a trained professional which is recorded, transcribed, edited and then returned to the patient, who, once they are satisfied with it, can share or bequeath the resulting ‘generativity’ document to people of their choosing.1 The potential benefit of the therapy for families and friends is a unique aspect of dignity therapy and evaluations with hospice patients in Canada, Australia, US and UK have shown that patients feel that it had helped them1,3,4 and that it had, or would, help their families.5 These studies focused largely on people with cancer, the majority of whom were being cared for at home. The generalisability of these findings to people with chronic non-malignant conditions, who may have psychological or spiritual concerns (although may not necessarily be in the palliative phase of illness) or may be being cared for in other settings, is uncertain.

Our study of the views of older people in care homes on dignity supported most of the themes informing the development of dignity therapy.6 However, there was no evidence that residents had major concerns about death (e.g. aftermath concerns). Support for the dignity model suggested that dignity therapy could be beneficial to care home residents. Quantitative findings from our mixed methods phase II randomised controlled trial (RCT) showed that, overall, residents in the intervention group felt that dignity therapy had helped them and that it would help their families.7 However, residents in the control group also felt that participation in the study had helped them, albeit less so than those who also received the therapy: this finding was also observed in trials of dignity therapy for palliative care patients.3,4 The source of these perceived benefits is not known. Qualitative studies can help answer such questions. Although qualitative studies are important in trials of complex interventions,8 particularly where there is uncertainty about the mechanism of action, they are uncommon.9 Participants’ views and experiences are an essential component of any evaluation.

sec.title: Aim
sec.p: The aim of this qualitative study is to explore and compare residents’ views on dignity therapy and taking part in the dignity therapy trial.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Further details of this trial are reported with the quantitative findings7 and in our protocol.10

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: The study was approved by the joint South London and Maudsley and the Institute of Psychiatry NHS Research Ethics Committee (24/11/2008, ref. no. 08/H0807/75) and met the requirements of the Local Research Governance Framework.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: This was a qualitative study embedded in a phase II RCT of dignity therapy. Quantitative and qualitative data were collected simultaneously and the quantitative analysis preceded this qualitative analysis.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants in the study were residents aged 65+ years with no major cognitive impairment (score of 15 or less on the Blessed Orientation-Memory-Concentration Test)11 living in one of 15 care homes in London, UK. All residents still in the study at follow-up were interviewed.

sec.title: Intervention group
sec.p: The intervention group received dignity therapy in addition to standard psychological and spiritual care.7 The study team (including all therapists/researchers) were trained to deliver dignity therapy by Professor Harvey Max Chochinov) (University of Manitoba & Cancercare Manitoba) who developed the therapy. Training included: the theoretical basis for the intervention; demonstrations of dignity therapy; a detailed overview of the manual; editing the dignity therapy documents; and working with residents to produce a document that would be helpful for them and other recipients. The standard framework of questions used in the therapy was given to residents after randomisation to give them the opportunity to think about their responses before the session. Dignity therapy interviews were tape-recorded, transcribed verbatim and then shaped into a narrative using a formatted editing process. This included clarifications, chronological corrections, tagging and editing any content that might inflict significant harm on recipients of the ‘generativity’ document (after discussion with the resident), and finding a suitable ending for the document which was appropriate to the overall message. Another session was arranged for the therapist to read the ‘generativity’ to the resident who was invited to make editorial suggestions. Once this document was finalised, it was given to the resident to share with anyone they chose. To assure quality, 14 (52%) therapy transcripts were reviewed by SH, PS, or a therapist working with Harvey Chochinov’s research group (who were evaluating of the intervention with hospice patients).

sec.title: Control group
sec.p: The control group received the usual psychological and spiritual care offered by homes and baseline and follow up interviews.

sec.title: Demographic measures
sec.p: We collected demographic information including: cognitive functioning (Blessed Orientation Memory Concentration test),11 performance status (Karnosfsky scores),12 ability to perform activities of daily living (Barthel scores),13 age, gender and ethnic group.

sec.title: Research interviews
sec.p: Details of randomisation and recruitment and the recruitment procedure are reported elsewhere.7,10 Both groups took part in face-to-face semi-structured interviews with one of three female researchers at 1-week and 8-week follow-ups. Two researchers were psychologists (both with MSc qualifications) and one was a palliative care nurse. One researcher (CG) is a co-author. None of the researchers worked in the care homes or had relationships with residents prior to commencement of the study. No information about the researchers was given to residents prior to their first meeting. The researchers also delivered the therapy, however, they did not recruit or collect follow up data on the residents to whom they delivered the therapy. All researchers were trained in the use of the topic guide, field notes were recorded, and interviews were discussed at regular team meetings. Researchers also recruited and obtained consent from the residents for the study. Qualitative interviews immediately followed completion of quantitative measures and were conducted in private in the resident’s care home. The interviews covered residents’ views on the therapy and/or taking part in the study. For example, they were asked if they felt that dignity therapy or taking part in the study helped them and if they felt that it had, or would have, helped their families. Follow up interviews were audio-recorded and transcribed verbatim. Transcripts of follow-up interviews were not returned to participants for comment and/or correction.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: We used the framework approach to qualitative analysis.14 This comprehensive and flexible approach has been developed specifically for applied (or policy-relevant) qualitative research in which the objectives of the research are typically set in advance, for example, exploring the proposed mechanisms of action of an intervention. This approach can be used for studies which are more descriptive than interpretative and is particularly suitable for comparing different groups. Since we were interested in summarising, in everyday terms, residents’ descriptions of how dignity therapy and taking part in the study had helped them, we stayed close to the data and to the surface of words and events. Consequently, our analysis was more descriptive than interpretative. We felt that minimally-theorised, or otherwise minimally-transformed or ‘spun’ answers to our questions15 would be most relevant for those interested in delivering dignity therapy. We use the term ‘theme’ to describe a more limited and concrete category than is often used in qualitative research. We conducted the analysis systematically and rigorously (Table 1), and used QSR NVivo (Version 8.0) to organise the data.

tr.td: 1. SH, CG and PS read the transcripts and field notes to familiarise themselves with the data.
2. SH, CG and PS independently developed frameworks and tested these by indexing 12 randomly selected transcripts (six control and six intervention).
3. SH, CG and PS compared, discussed and agreed a preliminary framework, which was developed further following discussion of indexing of the same transcripts.
4. SH, CG and PS agreed the final framework and developed a coding manual which included a description of themes and example quotes from participants.
5. CG indexed all transcripts using the final framework.
6. SH and PS checked the indexing. Any disagreements were resolved by discussion.

7. SH constructed charts for the intervention and control groups, containing the themes in the framework and quotes from participants. The charts facilitated comparison of the intervention and control groups.
8. CG and PS checked the charts and any disagreements were resolved by discussion.
9. SH, CG and PS agreed the interpretation of the data.
10. Participants were not asked to provide feedback on the findings.

sec.title: Participant characteristics
sec.p: Between October 2008 and December 2009, we recruited 60 of the 755 residents assessed for eligibility. Forty-nine residents were interviewed at 1-week follow-up (25/29 control group and 24/31 intervention group), and 36 residents were interviewed at 8-week follow-up (21 control, 15 intervention).7 The characteristics of participants are in Table 2.

sec.title: Interviews
sec.p: Mean follow-up interview times were 65 minutes at the 1-week follow-up and 72 minutes at the 8-week follow-up (including completion of questionnaires).

sec.title: Themes
sec.p: Residents’ views were represented in nine main themes (Table 3). Three themes were evident only in the intervention group: views on the generativity document; generativity; and reminiscence. Six themes were evident in both groups: refocusing; making a contribution; interaction with the researcher or therapist; diversion; not helping with their problems; and cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Impact on residents
sec.p: Some residents felt that their generativity documents were useful, well-written and made them feel important. They appreciated how editing resulted in a coherent document and being given the opportunity to make changes to drafts. For example, one gentleman, who was initially concerned about some of the content of his document following criticism from a family member, was delighted with the revised version.

disp-quote.p: [Revised document] … very good … better than the first … I appreciate it very much because … I never believe I would have … a document with my life story. So I’m very pleased with it … I’m so thankful that someone has come … to help me with … my life story. (Intervention, R33: 8-weeks)

sec.p: In contrast, other residents were relatively neutral about their documents. They found them difficult to read either because of problems with their eyesight or because they found it tiring to read. Although residents had agreed the final version, they still found minor errors due to memory lapses, and some still felt that they had not included enough information about some people or times in their lives. However, none of these were major concerns.

disp-quote.p: It’s a long life, you see … it can’t be [pause] explained in a document really … I felt it was a pity you didn’t know more about my very early life, because it was a happy home from the start. (Intervention, R9: 1-week)

sec.title: Impact on residents’ families
sec.p: Some residents had already given their generativity documents to the intended recipients, whilst others were planning to bequeath them after their death. Some residents felt that recipients would understand them better or learn more of their family history, although others pointed out that their families already knew all the information in their documents. Residents appreciated the opportunity of reminding their families of the more positive aspects of their lives or thought that their family might enjoy their amusing anecdotes. Some of the residents, who had already shared their documents, thought that this might improve current communication with their families (or for one resident, communication with a member of the care home staff) or prompt enjoyable reminiscence. Residents rarely spoke about dying, however, one felt that her document would be helpful for her funeral.

disp-quote.p: I can tell them about things getting better and better, and as I get older, to forget the troubles and think of the future … [member of care home staff name] got one … She says very good, very helpful … maybe she’ll understand me better. (Intervention, R28: 8-weeks)

I think they knew me pretty well before they got the document. But they, they have discovered some things they didn’t know … You see one way in which it could be useful is supposing [nieces’ names] were not available to arrange things when I die, supposing I live to be a hundred, they might be gone mightn’t they? [laughter] So it might be useful to have, keep it with my Will … because … people, you know, at a funeral people usually expect somebody to speak about the, the person who’s died, don’t they … it does contain a good deal of information about my background, you know. (Intervention, R14: 8-weeks)

sec.p: In contrast, other residents could see no potential benefits for recipients or felt that their documents could create problems, for example by raising long-standing family disagreements. Others had no immediate family or felt that potential recipients would not be interested in their document.

disp-quote.p: Well I haven’t got a family, you see … well they’re not immediate [siblings] … they might not like it, because I’ve referred to them here and there, and maybe they’d prefer not to be. So it’s … it’s a bit awkward … it’d be up to them how they view me, of course. Some might be, say, well that poor old devil had a hard time, and others will say, oh he must have been a lazy old bugger to spend his life like that, you know … Well they probably wouldn’t be in the least interested. (Intervention, R2: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Generativity
sec.p: Although one of the aims of dignity therapy is to help people deal with concerns that nothing of them will transcend death (generativity issues), only one resident mentioned that dignity therapy could help him to be remembered after his death, although this did not appear to have been a concern for him. He said, ‘for future generations, like future times, for my children and that, you know … to remember me by when I’m gone’ (Intervention, R38: 8-weeks).

sec.title: Reminiscence
sec.p: Several residents who received dignity therapy described how it had jogged or restored memories, both good and bad. This could help them to see how aspects of their past related to one another. Many enjoyed a rare opportunity to share their memories with an attentive listener, although one resident had felt sad when recalling unpleasant memories and another felt that it was more important to think of the future rather than dwell on the past.

disp-quote.p: Oh they’d send me into melancholy [memories]. Some of them were horrible … there’s no way it can be corrected [the past]. The time’s not on my side, as you know… As well as the bright moments, it brought back some of the not so brighter ones . (Intervention, R2: 8-weeks)

It’s brought back the past for me. And I like to dwell on the past, not in a bad way, just in good things … I didn’t have a bad past but especially certain instances that happened, and, and so I, I dwell on the good part. I’m not a one to talk of the past all the time, I’ve never done that, I think your future’s the best, you never know what’s there, there do you? (Intervention, R21: 1-week)

sec.title: Refocusing
sec.p: Residents in both groups described changes in direction or emphasis in their lives. Some who had received dignity therapy felt that they had gained new insight into themselves and that the therapy had helped them to solve problems, focus more on the positive aspects of lives, appreciate their achievements and the important people in their lives, and feel that their lives had been worthwhile. Residents in the control group felt that taking part had made them realise that things were not as bad as they could be. They described being more thoughtful and more contented and accepting of their current situation and the care they were receiving. Although one resident in the control group described gaining more insight into his past, this did not seem to be accompanied with increased feelings of pride or self-worth.

disp-quote.p: Well I did feel better about myself because … after a while you, you lose all connection with work and, and your colleagues, and so on, and so … you begin to wonder about how well you did it [laughs] … it boosted my morale a bit really … it has stimulated me to think more about life generally and … you know, not to just think oh well I’m coming to the end of it all. (Intervention, R54: 1-week)

I think it was a help … it gave me an insight to all that I have been through … I was thinking all through my life what I have done. The things that I’ve done, the way that I acted for the family. (Control, R59: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Making a contribution
sec.p: Many residents seemed to find satisfaction in the thought that they might be helping others. Some felt that it had made them feel useful or special. This theme was evident in both groups, but particularly prevalent in the control group. For some residents in the intervention group this was an additional benefit of taking part whilst for the control group this seemed to be a major benefit.

disp-quote.p: I feel that I’m not useless, you know … that I am … will help somebody, you know, apart from myself. (Intervention, R4: 8-weeks)
It makes me feel that I’m still relevant … I’m still able to contribute to some, see some good things in life. (Control, R51: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Interaction with the researcher or therapist
sec.p: This was a prevalent theme in both groups. Residents who received dignity therapy described the therapist, and sometimes the researcher conducting the follow up interviews, as kind, thoughtful or understanding. The residents appreciated having someone who cared and was interested in them and any problems they might have. Residents in the control group looked forward to the visits of the researcher. For some this was seen simply as enjoyable company, however, for others these visits seemed more meaningful: knowing someone was interested in them made them feel more worthwhile and they felt that they had benefited from the opportunity to talk about their problems with an empathetic listener.

disp-quote.p: I’m very happy to see you [researcher] … Yourself and [therapist] and it’s just a very, very wonderful … Well I must say I’m very fortunate to have you come … Well you see you can be left on the shelf, as it were, and nobody cares and this is … very grateful for people like you take interest in us … sharing my problem with someone I trust . (Intervention, R61: 1-week)

I can express myself to you where I can’t to people that work here … Having a lovely lady like you to talk to has given me more strength in my body and more … heart to go on, where otherwise I wanted to give up … Even a few weeks of living in here … I wanted to die … Seeing you … has given me the will to go on … You can get it off your chest, you can talk, and you know that the person you’re talking to is sensible and understands you. That is the main thing, you understand, you do really understand… I’ve known people here for years that I can’t talk to like I can talk to you. (Control, R4: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Diversion
sec.p: In contrast to the more substantial benefits described above, some residents in both groups felt that taking part in the study was helpful simply because it gave them something to do or think about: it was a change in routine and relieved boredom. They could forget their troubles or symptoms for a while. Here a sense that taking part in the study was something special was missing.

disp-quote.p: Well I think it does help you when you can talk to somebody and, you know, it helps to take things away and that … things like the sickness and that, you don’t feel, feel about it so much when you can talk to somebody. (Intervention, R50: 1-week)
I’ll be honest, it’s a happy break to get away from that room where you spend nearly all day. (Control, R43: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Not helping with problems
sec.p: Some residents in both groups felt that they had not been helped with the main problems they were experiencing. As one resident who had received dignity therapy pointed out, ‘there’s no cure for old age’ (Intervention, R29: 8-weeks). The problems residents felt that they needed help with involved coping with losses (such as loss of function, loss of freedom or the loss of their home) or distressing symptoms.

disp-quote.p: How can it be helping me? You should be doing something for me and speaking to these people … I want more freedom. Being cooped up here all day long. It’s not as if I’m … haven’t got my faculties about me, you know what I mean … I don’t wanna be here. (Intervention, R38: 1-week)

Well I’m still sitting here and I’m still … I’m still in, looking at the four walls and me window and [pause] it’s not, it’s not my, making my eyesight any better, or my hearing any better, the two things that … get me down. (Control, R5: 1-week)

sec.title: Cognitive impairment
sec.p: Dignity therapy is not, in its current form, recommended for people with significant cognitive impairment, as their generativity documents are likely to reflect a distorted sense of self which could be distressing for themselves and the recipients. Several residents in the intervention group felt that, since most residents in the care home had dementia or other communication problems, they would not benefit from dignity therapy. However, although we screened residents for cognitive impairment at the start of the study, some who had received the therapy did have problems recalling their experience of the study. One resident in the control group also had problems recalling their experience of the study.

disp-quote.p: I don’t remember much about it [dignity therapy] now, but I do remember it, yes … quite honestly I don’t know what the document was about now [laughs] it’s too long ago, so … After all, at my age … you can remember sort of some things and that, but things like that you just answer them and then they’ve gone [laughs]. (Intervention, R36: 8-weeks)
… as long as I can remember what I’m telling because, since I have my stroke, my memory become very slow and very, you know, it’s not like before. (Control, R53: 8-weeks)

sec.title: Changes over time
sec.p: Although there was some consistency between the two follow up periods for individuals, residents sometimes gave a view at one point in time which they did not mention at the other. This, however, did not seem to be related to particular themes: all themes were represented at both time points. Neither were there changes in opinion (e.g. saying that something was helpful at one interview and then saying it was unhelpful at the next interview, and vice versa).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Some residents were delighted with dignity therapy and described many benefits for themselves and their families. Our findings support some of the proposed mechanisms of action for this palliative care intervention for this population. However, our findings also draw attention to some of the potential problems in delivering this intervention to care home residents. Our study also shows that residents can benefit from taking part in sensitively-conducted research regardless of whether or not they receive the intended intervention.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations of the study
sec.p: The strengths and limitations of this study are those of the RCT.7 To the best of our knowledge this is the first published evaluation of dignity therapy in a care home setting using a randomised design with the inclusion of a longer-term follow-up than in other evaluations of dignity therapy. Furthermore, this qualitative study allowed us to explore participants’ views on the ways in which this intervention may or may not have been working in this setting, along with the potential benefits of taking part in research. The main limitationsof the study are the low response rate and the low baseline levels of distress in the sample.

sec.title: Perceived benefits
sec.p: The perceived benefits of dignity therapy are evident across some of our themes and support some of the proposed mechanisms of action of this intervention (pride, hopefulness and care tenor). The focus on the achievements of residents, and recording these in their generativity documents, seemed to bolster a sense of pride and hopefulness in some residents. Care tenor was clearly evident in reports of their enjoyment of the visits of therapists and researchers. We suspect that the intervention sometimes took longer to deliver than expected7 because residents prolonged meetings: and they quickly realised that if they requested editorial changes to their documents then we would return.

However, most of the themes from the dignity model2 which informed the development of dignity therapy1 and relate to the proposed mechanisms of action were not evident. Residents did not seem to be concerned about whether or not their life had stood for something; or that they would have influence that would transcend death (generativity); or about the problems that their death would impose on others (aftermath concerns); or that their essence remained whole (continuity of self); or being unable to identify with previously held roles (role preservation). This is consistent with the low baseline levels of distress in our sample (and other published evaluations of dignity therapy)1,3,4 and an apparent lack of concern about death observed in our earlier study of the views of care home residents on maintaining dignity.6 Rather than ameliorating generativity or aftermath concerns, generativity documents were sometimes valued more for their more immediate benefits of improving communication and additional opportunities to reminisce. Many older people enjoy reminiscing and residents felt that this was a benefit of the intervention. However, although it is pleasing that residents enjoyed this aspect of the intervention, the therapeutic aim of dignity therapy is not simply to describe memories but to engage more in positive evaluation (e.g. focus on achievements etc.) as it is a life review style therapy. Reminiscence is often encouraged in care homes, however, this is usually done with a peer group and aims to increase integration and improve memory.

With the exception of benefits relating specifically to generativity documents, it was often not possible to differentiate the benefits of dignity therapy from those of taking part in the study. There seemed to be a strong sense of pride underlying residents’ feelings that, by taking part in the study, they were making an important contribution and this was evident in both groups. The potential benefits of feeling that they were making a significant contribution has been reported in other studies of nursing home residents16 and in palliative care patients and carers.17 Altruism and a wish to make a contribution is a motivator to participate in RCTs18 and in palliative care research.19,20 Completion of questionnaires focusing on any concerns or problems that they might be experiencing alongside the more in-depth qualitative interviews could also have been beneficial to residents in both groups. Researchers (and therapists) were selected and trained to work with older people in care homes. They treated residents with kindness, humanity and respect: these are core values of medical professionalism which are often overlooked in the time-pressured culture of modern health care.21 Although only one group received dignity therapy, both groups received ‘dignity conserving care’. Our study, and other evaluations of dignity therapy, support the notion of palliative care research as ‘a therapeutic opportunity’.22

sec.title: Challenges
sec.p: Although the perceived benefits of taking part in the study are encouraging, some residents were less enthusiastic. Although no participants felt that they had been seriously adversely affected by taking part, difficulties with the therapy can arise. Although generativity documents aim to capture the ‘essence’ of residents, they have lived long lives and some seemed to want a biography of their lives. Deciding what to include in generativity documents can be a difficult decision as recipients (usually family members) can be critical of the content of documents and residents concerned about potential responses, particularly when there are difficult family issues. Individuals might not be mentioned, or not mentioned enough, events considered important by recipients omitted, and witty comments or well-meaning advice taken the wrong way. Avoiding these pitfalls depends on the skill of the therapist, who could not foresee all of these issues. Residents often have no close family or friends and, although some are pleased to have the document for the pleasure of reading it themselves, there can be a sense of sadness when there is nobody who cares enough to appreciate receiving it. Dignity therapy has been shown to be particularly beneficial to patients who feel that it will help their families.1

Some residents recall distressing events or want to talk about unresolved issues, their symptoms or disabilities, their losses, loneliness, concerns about being in the care home and the care they are receiving. For some, this is the only opportunity that they have to talk about these issues to an attentive listener. In contrast to life review, in which participants typically work at coming to terms with more difficult memories over several sessions,23 dignity therapy usually involves a single session focusing more on achievements and happier memories. Therapists do not have the time or the expertise to help people deal with problems, although they can suggest that they seek the help they need. Since participants in published evaluations of dignity therapy are, overall, not distressed there is a need to explore more rigorously the impact of this intervention on distressed individuals, along with consideration of how therapists should deal with patients’ intense regrets and life-long conflicts.24 However, few residents were distressed and several pointed out that although the therapy had not helped them because they had not needed help, they had enjoyed it anyway. Finally, cognitive impairment is likely to be a particular problem for this population. The vast majority of residents in these homes were excluded from this study for this reason. Some of those who had passed our cognitive screening reported minor and major memory lapses. The former resulted in repeated visits to correct documents, the latter resulted in inability to recall the therapy. Cognitive impairment at follow-up might have been temporary (having a ‘bad day’ ) or permanent (resulting from a relatively rapid deterioration in health).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Dignity therapy in its current form is likely to be beneficial to some care home residents, albeit the small minority who have the desire and the capacity to engage in such an intervention. However, in view of the relatively small proportion of residents who are likely to benefit from this intervention and the time it takes to deliver it, the cost of offering this therapy as usual care needs to be considered particularly if other interventions, such as reminiscence therapy, are already in place. Whether or not dignity therapy helps distressed residents, and the most effective way of screening for those residents who might benefit from it, needs to be determined: perhaps by identifying those with concerns particularly likely to be helped by the therapy. Items from the Patient Dignity Inventory25 could be used as these relate directly to the themes from the model of dignity in the terminally ill2 which informed the structure content and therapeutic tone of dignity therapy1 (i.e. generativity, continuity of self, role preservation, maintenance of pride, hopefulness, aftermath concerns and care tenor). It is possible that residents with moderate cognitive impairment, and their families, might benefit from a slightly modified protocol where family members contribute to the therapy interview. Although, some interventions were challenging, therapists often enjoyed delivering the therapy as much as the residents who received it. However, we feel that ongoing supervision and support, similar to that given to counsellors and psychotherapists, is needed to help therapists deal with more unusual or difficult cases.
